title: Luke Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Luke chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Luke Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Luke Chapter 3.

questions.question: In the fifteenth year of whose reign did the events of Luke Chapter 3 begin?
questions.correctAnswer: Tiberius Caesar
questions.explanation: Luke 3:1 states that these events began in the fifteenth year of Tiberius Caesar's reign.

questions.question: Who was the governor of Judaea during the time John received the word of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Pontius Pilate
questions.explanation: Luke 3:1 mentions Pontius Pilate as governor of Judaea at that time.

questions.question: Where did the word of God come unto John the son of Zacharias?
questions.correctAnswer: In the wilderness
questions.explanation: Luke 3:2 says the word of God came unto John in the wilderness.

questions.question: What was John preaching about throughout the country around Jordan?
options: Baptism of repentance for the remission of sins
questions.correctAnswer: Baptism of repentance for the remission of sins
questions.explanation: Luke 3:3 states John preached the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the _______, make his paths straight.'
questions.correctAnswer: Lord
questions.explanation: Luke 3:4 quotes Isaiah, saying 'Prepare ye the way of the Lord.'

questions.question: What did John call the multitude that came to be baptized by him?
questions.correctAnswer: Generation of vipers
questions.explanation: Luke 3:7 refers to the multitude as 'O generation of vipers'.

questions.question: According to Luke 3:9, what will happen to every tree that does not bring forth good fruit?
options: It will be hewn down and cast into the fire
questions.correctAnswer: It will be hewn down and cast into the fire
questions.explanation: Luke 3:9 says the axe is laid to the root of trees that do not bring good fruit, and they are cut down and burned.

questions.question: What did John tell those who had two coats?
options: Share with him who has none
questions.correctAnswer: Share with him who has none
questions.explanation: Luke 3:11 says he who has two coats should impart to him who has none.

questions.question: What instruction did John give to the publicans when they asked what they should do?
options: Exact no more than that which is appointed
questions.correctAnswer: Exact no more than that which is appointed
questions.explanation: Luke 3:13 records John's answer to the publicans to exact no more than what is appointed.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 3:14, soldiers were told to accuse others falsely.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 3:14 instructs soldiers to do no violence, accuse no one falsely, and be content with their wages.

questions.question: Who did Herod imprison according to Luke 3:20?
questions.correctAnswer: John the Baptist
questions.explanation: Luke 3:20 states that Herod shut up John in prison.

questions.question: What happened immediately after Jesus was baptized according to Luke 3:21-22?
options: The heaven opened and the Holy Ghost descended like a dove
questions.correctAnswer: The heaven opened and the Holy Ghost descended like a dove
questions.explanation: Luke 3:21-22 describes the heavens opening and the Holy Ghost descending on Jesus like a dove.

questions.question: At about what age did Jesus begin his ministry as mentioned in Luke 3:23?
questions.correctAnswer: About thirty years
questions.explanation: Luke 3:23 says Jesus began to be about thirty years of age.

questions.question: True or False: John said he baptized with the Holy Ghost and fire.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 3:16 states John baptizes with water, but one mightier will baptize with the Holy Ghost and fire.

questions.question: True or False: Luke 3 includes a genealogy of Jesus tracing back to Adam and God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 3:23-38 provides a genealogy of Jesus tracing back to Adam, who is called the son of God.

medium.title: Luke Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Luke Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of judgment. Based on Luke 3, what practical advice does John the Baptist give to show true repentance?
options: Bring forth fruits worthy of repentance
Give large offerings at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Bring forth fruits worthy of repentance
questions.explanation: Luke 3:8 instructs to bring forth fruits worthy of repentance, showing that genuine repentance involves a change in behavior and actions, not just words or rituals. This is supported by verses 3:3, 3:7, and 3:9 where repentance is linked with producing good fruit and turning away from sin.

questions.question: How does Luke 3 teach about generosity and sharing with those in need?
options: If anyone has two coats, share with the one who has none
Save all possessions for personal use
questions.correctAnswer: If anyone has two coats, share with the one who has none
questions.explanation: Luke 3:11 teaches generosity by telling those who have two coats to share with those who have none. This practical instruction emphasizes stewardship and caring for others in daily life. Verses 3:11, 3:12-14 also show honesty and fairness in work and social dealings.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to live with integrity in the workplace. Based on Luke 3, what biblical principle would you share?
options: Do not accuse anyone falsely and be content with your wages
Work only enough to avoid punishment
Take advantage of others to gain more
Ignore rules if no one is watching
questions.correctAnswer: Do not accuse anyone falsely and be content with your wages
questions.explanation: Luke 3:14 advises soldiers to avoid violence and false accusations, and to be content with their wages. This teaches honesty, fairness, and contentment in work, which applies broadly to all believers in their daily labor. Verses 3:13-14 reinforce ethical behavior and contentment.

questions.question: What does Luke 3 suggest about humility and recognizing one's place before God?
options: John said he was not worthy to unloose the latchet of the coming one's shoes
John claimed he was the Messiah
John demanded worship from the people
John declared himself greater than the coming one
questions.correctAnswer: John said he was not worthy to unloose the latchet of the coming one's shoes
questions.explanation: Luke 3:16 shows John's humility by stating he is not worthy even to untie the shoes of the one coming after him. This teaches believers the importance of humility before God and recognizing His supremacy. This humility is contrasted with the people's expectation in verse 3:15 and John’s recognition of a mightier one.

questions.question: How does Luke 3 encourage believers to persevere through trials and correction?
options: John reproved Herod for his sins despite danger
Avoid all confrontation to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: John reproved Herod for his sins despite danger
questions.explanation: Luke 3:19-20 shows John boldly reproving Herod for his wrongs even though it led to imprisonment. This teaches perseverance in standing for righteousness and truth despite opposition. The passage encourages believers to trust God and remain faithful in trials (also see verses 3:18 and 3:20).

questions.question: A believer wants to deepen their spiritual discipline. What does Luke 3 show about the role of prayer and seeking God’s presence?
options: Jesus prayed when baptized and heaven opened to Him
Prayer should be done only on special occasions
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus prayed when baptized and heaven opened to Him
questions.explanation: Luke 3:21 describes Jesus praying during His baptism, which led to heaven opening and the Holy Spirit descending. This highlights prayer as a vital spiritual discipline and a way to experience God’s presence. Prayer is shown as essential for devotion and connection with God.

questions.question: What biblical principle about evangelism and being a witness is taught in Luke 3?
options: John preached repentance and the coming salvation to all the country around Jordan
Evangelism should be done only by priests
Only speak about God in the temple
Wait for others to ask before sharing
questions.correctAnswer: John preached repentance and the coming salvation to all the country around Jordan
questions.explanation: Luke 3:3 shows John actively preaching repentance and baptism for the remission of sins to all the surrounding country. This demonstrates the importance of boldly sharing the Gospel and calling others to faith and repentance as a witness.

questions.question: How does Luke 3 teach about contentment and avoiding greed?
options: Soldiers were told to be content with their wages
Seek to increase wealth by any means
Demand more than what is fair
questions.correctAnswer: Soldiers were told to be content with their wages
questions.explanation: Luke 3:14 instructs soldiers to be content with their wages and not to do violence or accuse falsely. This teaches contentment with what God provides and warns against greed and dishonesty. It encourages believers to live with gratitude and integrity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 3, John the Baptist encouraged people to rely solely on their heritage from Abraham for salvation.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 3:8 clearly states that John warned the people not to say 'We have Abraham to our father' as a basis for salvation, because God can raise children to Abraham from stones. This teaches that faith and repentance, not heritage alone, are essential for salvation.

questions.question: True or False: John baptized with water but said someone mightier would baptize with the Holy Ghost and fire.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 3:16 states John baptized with water but declared that one mightier than him would come to baptize with the Holy Ghost and fire, indicating the coming of Jesus and the Holy Spirit's work.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Luke 3, the voice from heaven said to Jesus, 'Thou art my ______ Son; in thee I am well pleased.'
questions.correctAnswer: beloved
questions.explanation: Luke 3:22 records the voice from heaven declaring Jesus as God's beloved Son, affirming His divine approval and identity.

questions.question: What does Luke 3 teach about humility in relation to spiritual leadership?
options: John acknowledged he was not worthy to untie the shoes of the one coming after him
John demanded honor and recognition before preaching
John claimed he was the greatest prophet
questions.correctAnswer: John acknowledged he was not worthy to untie the shoes of the one coming after him
questions.explanation: Luke 3:16 highlights John's humility in recognizing the superior authority of the coming Messiah. This teaches spiritual leaders to be humble and aware of God’s greater work.

questions.question: How does Luke 3 instruct believers to respond to God's judgment and mercy?
options: Produce good fruits, or be cut down like trees without fruit
Ignore warnings and continue as before
Rely on heritage to escape judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Produce good fruits, or be cut down like trees without fruit
questions.explanation: Luke 3:9 warns that every tree not producing good fruit will be cut down and cast into the fire, symbolizing the necessity of genuine repentance and obedience in response to God's mercy and judgment.

questions.question: What does Luke 3 teach about the importance of honesty in financial dealings?
options: Publicans should not exact more than appointed
Cheat whenever possible to gain advantage
Ignore rules if it benefits you
questions.correctAnswer: Publicans should not exact more than appointed
questions.explanation: Luke 3:13 instructs tax collectors (publicans) to collect no more than what is appointed, teaching honesty and integrity in financial matters.

questions.question: According to Luke 3, how should believers live in anticipation of the coming Messiah?
options: Prepare the way by repentance and righteous living
Focus only on rituals without heart change
Rely on others to do the preparation
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare the way by repentance and righteous living
questions.explanation: Luke 3:4-6 quotes Isaiah about preparing the way of the Lord by making paths straight and filling valleys, symbolizing the call to repentance and righteous living in expectation of the Messiah.

hard.title: Luke Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Luke Chapter 3.

questions.question: In Luke 3:4-6, the prophecy quoted is from Isaiah. What is the literary device used in the description of preparing the way for the Lord?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The passage in Luke 3:4-6 uses parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device seen in Isaiah, where phrases like 'Every valley shall be filled, every mountain and hill brought low' correspond to prepare the way of the Lord, making paths straight.

questions.question: What historical figures anchor the dating of John the Baptist's ministry in Luke 3:1-2?
options: Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate, Herod, Philip, Annas, and Caiaphas
Augustus Caesar, Herod the Great, Caiaphas, and Nicodemus
Nero Caesar, Pilate, Herod Antipas, and John the Apostle
Claudius Caesar, Annas, Caiaphas, and Zechariah
questions.correctAnswer: Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate, Herod, Philip, Annas, and Caiaphas
questions.explanation: Luke 3:1-2 precisely mentions these rulers and high priests to date the beginning of John’s ministry within the political and religious context of Judea, anchoring the narrative historically.

questions.question: What symbolic meaning does the 'baptism with the Holy Ghost and with fire' in Luke 3:16 imply in the broader biblical context?
options: A ritual cleansing similar to Old Testament sacrifices
A literal fire to burn the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Purification and empowerment for mission
questions.explanation: Luke 3:16 foreshadows the coming of the Messiah who will baptize not only with water but with the Holy Spirit and fire, symbolizing both purification from sin and empowerment to spread God’s kingdom, consistent with Acts 2.

questions.question: How does John’s address to the crowd as a 'generation of vipers' in Luke 3:7 reflect Old Testament prophetic rhetoric?
options: It echoes the serpent imagery used in Isaiah and Psalms to denote deceit and danger.
It is a unique New Testament invention with no Old Testament parallel.
It directly quotes from the Ten Commandments.
It alludes to the covenant with David.
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the serpent imagery used in Isaiah and Psalms to denote deceit and danger.
questions.explanation: The term 'generation of vipers' in Luke 3:7 employs serpent imagery common in Old Testament prophetic literature (e.g., Isaiah 59:5, Psalm 58), symbolizing deceitfulness and impending judgment.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by John’s call in Luke 3:8 to 'bring forth fruits worthy of repentance'?
options: Ethical transformation as evidence of genuine repentance
Genealogical descent from Abraham as salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Ethical transformation as evidence of genuine repentance
questions.explanation: Luke 3:8 stresses that mere lineage (Abrahamic descent) is insufficient; true repentance must result in tangible ethical changes, reflecting the prophetic demand for inward and outward holiness.

questions.question: In Luke 3:9, the imagery of the axe being laid to the root of the trees signifies what kind of eschatological motif?
options: Imminent divine judgment on those not producing good fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Imminent divine judgment on those not producing good fruit
questions.explanation: The axe imagery in Luke 3:9 symbolizes God’s judgment, a common eschatological motif in both Old and New Testament prophetic literature indicating separation of the righteous (wheat) from the wicked (chaff).

questions.question: How does John’s practical advice to soldiers in Luke 3:14 reflect the socio-political context of Roman occupation?
options: It promotes non-violence and contentment with wages amid Roman military service.
It commands them to collect heavy taxes.
It orders them to isolate themselves from society.
questions.correctAnswer: It promotes non-violence and contentment with wages amid Roman military service.
questions.explanation: Luke 3:14 instructs soldiers to avoid violence and false accusations and to be content, reflecting an ethical stance that respects personal integrity under Roman occupation without inciting revolt.

questions.question: The genealogy from Adam to Jesus in Luke 3:23-38 serves what literary and theological purpose?
options: To emphasize Jesus’ universal humanity and divine sonship
To prove Jesus’ royal lineage from King David only
To show Jesus as a priest from Aaron’s line
To focus solely on Jesus’ earthly father Joseph
questions.correctAnswer: To emphasize Jesus’ universal humanity and divine sonship
questions.explanation: By tracing Jesus’ lineage back to Adam and ultimately God (Luke 3:38), the author highlights Jesus’ connection to all humanity and divine origin, contrasting with Matthew’s focus on Abraham and David.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Holy Ghost descending 'in a bodily shape like a dove' in Luke 3:22?
options: It symbolizes purity, peace, and the presence of God’s Spirit upon Jesus.
It indicates an actual bird physically landing on Jesus.
It is a metaphor for the Roman eagle.
It represents the zodiac sign of Pisces.
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes purity, peace, and the presence of God’s Spirit upon Jesus.
questions.explanation: The dove is a biblical symbol of purity and peace, and its bodily shape descending upon Jesus in Luke 3:22 signifies the anointing of the Holy Spirit marking the Messiah’s divine approval.

questions.question: What is the significance of John being imprisoned by Herod as narrated in Luke 3:19-20?
options: It reflects the conflict between prophetic authority and political power.
It implies John’s rejection by the people.
It indicates a peaceful relationship between John and Herod.
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the conflict between prophetic authority and political power.
questions.explanation: John’s imprisonment for reproving Herod's unlawful marriage (Luke 3:19-20) highlights the tension between prophetic witness and corrupt political rulers, a recurring theme in the Bible.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 3:11, John instructs those with two coats to keep them for themselves.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 3:11 explicitly commands those who have two coats to share with those who have none, emphasizing generosity as evidence of repentance.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is directly referenced in Luke 3:4 as the source of the prophecy about preparing the way?
questions.correctAnswer: Esaias (Isaiah)
questions.explanation: Luke 3:4 quotes the prophet Isaiah (referred to as Esaias in the Greek text), specifically Isaiah 40:3, emphasizing the fulfillment of prophetic anticipation.

questions.question: How does John’s baptism ministry in Luke 3:3 typify Old Testament purification rites and foreshadow New Testament themes?
options: It acts as a ritual of repentance preparing for the coming Messiah and the forgiveness of sins.
It is simply a new invention unrelated to Old Testament practices.
It replaces circumcision as the covenant sign.
It is a political statement against Rome.
questions.correctAnswer: It acts as a ritual of repentance preparing for the coming Messiah and the forgiveness of sins.
questions.explanation: John’s baptism in Luke 3:3 echoes Jewish purification traditions but introduces a forward-looking repentance for the remission of sins, anticipating Jesus’ redemptive work.

questions.question: What is the significance of John saying he is 'not worthy to unloose the latchet of his shoes' in Luke 3:16?
options: It expresses humility before the Messiah, reflecting Jewish customs of servant roles.
It means John could literally not untie shoes.
It suggests John was physically weak.
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses humility before the Messiah, reflecting Jewish customs of servant roles.
questions.explanation: In Luke 3:16, John humbly acknowledges the superiority of the coming Christ by referencing the menial task of untying a master's sandals, a sign of deep respect and humility.

questions.question: How do the instructions given by John to the tax collectors in Luke 3:13 reflect the ethical demands of the covenant?
options: They emphasize honesty and fairness, urging them not to extort beyond what is appointed.
They allow them to collect as much as they want.
They command them to stop collecting taxes entirely.
They focus only on ritual purity, ignoring ethics.
questions.correctAnswer: They emphasize honesty and fairness, urging them not to extort beyond what is appointed.
questions.explanation: Luke 3:13 requires tax collectors to act justly by collecting only what is due, resonating with covenantal themes of justice and righteousness in the Law.

theological.title: Luke Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Luke Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Luke 3, John the Baptist preaches a baptism of repentance. What is the primary purpose of this baptism according to the text?
options: For entrance into the kingdom of God
For initiation into the Jewish community
questions.correctAnswer: For the remission of sins
questions.explanation: Luke 3:3 states John preached 'the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins.' This aligns with Acts 2:38, Mark 1:4, and Hebrews 9:22, emphasizing repentance and forgiveness of sins as central to Christian baptism.

questions.question: John the Baptist quotes Isaiah when describing his mission. What is the central metaphor used to describe his role?
options: A voice crying in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: A voice crying in the wilderness
questions.explanation: Luke 3:4 quotes Isaiah, 'The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord.' This metaphor is used in Isaiah 40:3, Malachi 3:1, and Matthew 3:3, portraying John as the forerunner preparing the Messiah’s coming.

questions.question: What warning does John give to the crowd coming to be baptized?
options: O generation of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
questions.correctAnswer: O generation of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
questions.explanation: In Luke 3:7, John calls the crowd 'a generation of vipers' warning them to flee coming wrath, echoing themes found in Matthew 3:7 and Romans 1:18 about divine judgment and the need for repentance.

questions.question: What does John say about relying on Abraham as a spiritual heritage?
options: God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham
Faith is unnecessary if you are Abraham’s seed
questions.correctAnswer: God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham
questions.explanation: Luke 3:8 teaches that relying solely on Abrahamic descent is insufficient because God can raise up children to Abraham from stones. This reflects Galatians 3:7 and Romans 9:6-8 emphasizing faith over physical ancestry.

questions.question: According to Luke 3, what will happen to every tree that does not bear good fruit?
options: It will be cut down and cast into the fire
It will be pruned and nurtured
It will be blessed by God
It will be left to grow
questions.correctAnswer: It will be cut down and cast into the fire
questions.explanation: Luke 3:9 states the axe is laid to the root of the trees that do not bear good fruit and they will be cut down and burned, symbolizing divine judgment consistent with Matthew 7:19 and John 15:6.

questions.question: What practical ethical instructions does John give to those who ask, 'What shall we do then?'
options: Share your coat and food with those who have none
Offer sacrifices and keep the law strictly
questions.correctAnswer: Share your coat and food with those who have none
questions.explanation: Luke 3:10-11 records John’s call for social justice and generosity, emphasizing active repentance through loving deeds, in line with Micah 6:8, Isaiah 1:17, and James 1:27.

questions.question: What does John instruct tax collectors to do when they ask what they should do?
options: Exact no more than that which is appointed to them
Give all their earnings to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Exact no more than that which is appointed to them
questions.explanation: Luke 3:13 shows John telling tax collectors to be honest and not extort more than what is required, reflecting Old Testament ethics in Leviticus 19:13 and Proverbs 11:1.

questions.question: What does John say to soldiers who ask about their conduct?
options: Do violence to no man, neither accuse any falsely; and be content with your wages
Take more than your wages to be generous
questions.correctAnswer: Do violence to no man, neither accuse any falsely; and be content with your wages
questions.explanation: Luke 3:14 commands soldiers to act justly and avoid abuse of power, consistent with teachings in Exodus 22:21-24, Romans 13:3-4, and 1 Peter 2:18.

questions.question: How does John describe the one mightier than himself who is coming?
options: He will baptize with the Holy Ghost and with fire
He will baptize only with water
He will be a political king
He will not baptize at all
questions.correctAnswer: He will baptize with the Holy Ghost and with fire
questions.explanation: Luke 3:16 contrasts John’s water baptism with the coming Messiah’s baptism by the Holy Spirit and fire, echoing prophetic expectations in Isaiah 4:4, Ezekiel 36:25-27, and Acts 1:5.

questions.question: What is the role of the fan in the hand of the mightier one, according to John’s prophecy?
options: To thoroughly purge and separate wheat from chaff
To gather all people into one body
questions.correctAnswer: To thoroughly purge and separate wheat from chaff
questions.explanation: Luke 3:17 describes the fan as a tool for judgment, separating the righteous (wheat) from the wicked (chaff), paralleling imagery in Matthew 3:12, Psalm 1:4-6, and Malachi 3:2-3.

questions.question: Why was John the Baptist imprisoned by Herod according to Luke 3?
options: For reproving Herod about Herodias, his brother's wife
questions.correctAnswer: For reproving Herod about Herodias, his brother's wife
questions.explanation: Luke 3:19-20 shows John’s imprisonment was due to his courageous rebuke of Herod’s unlawful marriage, consistent with prophetic calls for holiness in Ezekiel 22:26 and Amos 2:7.

questions.question: What significant event occurs immediately after Jesus is baptized according to Luke 3?
options: The Holy Ghost descends in bodily shape like a dove
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Ghost descends in bodily shape like a dove
questions.explanation: Luke 3:21-22 records the Holy Spirit descending on Jesus like a dove, confirming his divine Sonship, aligned with Matthew 3:16-17, John 1:32-34, and Acts 10:38.

questions.question: What does the voice from heaven declare about Jesus after his baptism?
options: Thou art my beloved Son; in thee I am well pleased
This is my servant, chosen and faithful
The Lamb of God who takes away sin
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art my beloved Son; in thee I am well pleased
questions.explanation: Luke 3:22 records God's voice affirming Jesus as His beloved Son, echoing Psalm 2:7, Isaiah 42:1, and 1 John 3:1 about the divine sonship of Christ.

questions.question: According to Luke 3, approximately how old was Jesus when he began his public ministry?
questions.correctAnswer: About thirty years of age
questions.explanation: Luke 3:23 states Jesus was about thirty years old when starting his ministry, consistent with Jewish customs for priestly service as seen in Numbers 4:3 and the age of David when anointed (1 Samuel 16:1).

questions.question: The genealogy in Luke 3 traces Jesus' lineage back to whom?
options: Noah, the survivor of the flood
Abraham, the father of the nation
questions.correctAnswer: Adam, the son of God
questions.explanation: Luke 3:38 traces Jesus’ genealogy back to Adam, emphasizing Jesus’ connection to all humanity and ultimately to God, supporting Genesis 1:27, Romans 5:12-19, and 1 Corinthians 15:22.
